body.p:
Humboldt, in his Travel@ to the Equinoctial Regions
of the New Continent, relates a touching example of
maternal affection.

Near the confluence of the Atabapo and the Rio Jerni,
there is a granite hummock that riscs on the we@tern
bank, near the mouth of the Guaosiau; it is called the
Rock of the Guabiba Woman, or the Rock of the Mo-
ther, (Piedra de la Madre,) from the trait of maternal
affection attached to it.

“If,” says the enterpri@ng Humboldt, “in these soli-
tary scene@, man scarcely leaves behind him any traces
of his existence, it is doubly humiliating for a European
to see perpetuated by the name of a rock, by one of those
imperisheble monuments of nature, the remembrance of
the moral degradation of our species, and the contrast
between the virtuo of a savage, and the barbarism of
civilised man.

“In 1797, the missionary of San Fernando bad led
bis Indians to the mouth of the Rio Guaviate, on one of
these @ile ineursions which are prohibited alike by
religion and the Spanish laws. They found, in an In@ian
but, a Guahiba mothor with three children, two of whom
were still infants. They were occupied in preparing the
flour of c@ava. Resistance was impossible; the father
was gone to fish, and the mother tried in @in to flee
with her ehildren. Scarcely had she reached the @van-
nah, when she was se@ed by the Indians of the mission.
who go to hunt men, like the whites and the negroes in
Africa. The mother and her children were found, and
dragged to the bank of the river. The monk, seated in
bis boat, waited the issuc of an expedition of which he
partook not the danger. Had the mother made too vio-
lent a resistance, the Indians would have killed her, for
every thing is permitted when they go to the conquest
of souls, (à la conquista capiritual,) and it is children
in patticular they seck to capture, in order to treat them,
in the mission, as poito@, or slaves of the Christian@
The prisoners were carried to San Pernondo, in the hope
that the mother would be unable to find her way back
to her home by land. Fur from those children who had
@companied their father on the day on which she had
been carried off, this un@appy woman showed signs of
the deepest despait. She attempted to take back to he@
family the children who bad been @ away by the
missionary, und fled with them repeatedly from the vil-
lago of San Fernando; but the Indians never failed to
seize her anew; and the @ssionary, after having caused
her to be mercilessly heat@, took the cruel resolution of
separating the mother from the two children who had
been carried @ with her. She was conveyed @ to-
ward the mi@ons of the Rio Negro, going up to the
Atabapo. S@htly bound, she was seated at the bow of
the boat, iguorant of the fate that awaited her; but she
judged by the direction of the sun, that she was removed
farther and farther from her hut and her native country.
She suec@led in breaking her bonds, throw herself into
the water, and swam to the left bank of the Atahapo.
The current carried her to a shelf of rock, which bear-
her name to this day. She landed, and took shelter in
the woods; but the president of the missions ordered
the Inlians to row to the shore, and follow the truces of
the Gual@. In the evening, she was brought back.
Stretehrd upon the rock, la Piedra de la Madre, a cruel
punishment was inflicted on her with those straps of
manatce leather which serve for whips in that country.
and with which the alcades are always furni@ This
unhappy woman, her hands tied behind her back with
strong stalks of maracure, was then dragged to the mis-
sion of Javita.

“She was there thrown into one of the caravanseras,
that are called Casa del Rey. It was the rainy scason,
and the night was profoundly dark. Porests, till then
believed to be impenetrable, separated the mission of
Javita from that of San Fernando, which was twenty-
five leagues distant in a straight line. No other path is
known than that of the rivers; no man ever attempted
to go by land from one village to another, were they only
a few leagues apart. But such difficulties do not stop a
mother, who is soparated from her children. Her chil-
dren are at San P@rnando de Atabapo; she must find
them again; she must exceute her project of delivering
them from the hands of the Christians, of bringing them
back to their father on the banks of the Guaviare. The
Guahiba was carelessly guarded in the caravansera. Her
arms being wounded, the Indians of Javita bad loosened
her bonds, unknown to the missionary and the alcades.
She succeeded, by the help of her teeth, in breaking
them entircly; disappeared duting the night; and at the
fourth rising sun, was seen at the mission of San Fer-
nando, hovering around the hut where her children were
confined. ‘What the woman performed,’ added the
missionary, who gave us this sad narrative, ‘the most
robust Indian would not have ventured to undertake.
She traversed the woods at a scason when the sky is
constantly covered with clouds, and the sun, during
whole days, appears but for a few minutes. Did the
course of the waters direct her way! The inundations
of the rivers forced her to go far from the banks of the
main stream, through the midst of woods, where the
movement of the waters is almost imp@ceptible. How
often must she have been stopped by the thorny lianas,
that form a net work around the trunks they entwine!
How often must she have swam across the rivulets that
run into the Atabapo!’ This unfortunate woman was
asked how she had su@tained herself during the four
days! She said, ‘that, exhausted with fatigue, she could
find no other noutishment than those great black ants,
called rachac@, which climb the trees in long bands, to
suspend on them their re@inou@ nests.’ We pressed the
missionary to tell us whether the Guahiba had peace-
fally enjoyed the happiness of remaining with her chil-
dren; and if any repentance had followed this excess of
cruelty. He would not satisfy our curiosity; but at our
return from the Rio Negro, we learnt that the Indian
mother was not allowed time to cure her wounds; but
was again separated from her children, and sent to one
of the missions of the Upper Oroonoko. There she
died, refusing all kind of nourishment, as the savages do
in great @lamities.

“Such is the remembronce annexed to this fatal rock,
to Piedra de la Mudre.”
